awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Modeling the Spatial and Temporal Dynamics of Vector-borne Diseases in Florida: The Case of Zika Outbreak in 2016
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop mathematical models to study the dynamics of Zika virus introduced to southern Florida.  The investigators will carry out mathematical, statistical and computational analyses of these models to better understand factors affecting the geographical spread of Zika. Several vector-borne diseases (VBDs), such as dengue, chikungunya and Zika, have been imported into Florida, caused local outbreaks (dengue in 2009-2010 and 2013, chikungunya in 2014, Zika in 2016), and posed major public health problems. Dengue, chikungunya and Zika share the same primary mosquito vectors, Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus, both abundant in Florida and capable of transmitting several other diseases. The transmission cycle of these VBDs is heavily influenced by seasonal changes, climate conditions, and human movement. Based on data from 2016 Zika outbreaks in Miami Beach, Wynwood, and Little River in Florida, they will build and calibrate models including the age structure of both hosts and vectors as well as the effects of seasonality to study the spatial and temporal dynamics and spread of Zika in Florida. The objectives are to be better prepared to anticipate and respond to similar reemerging arboviruses such as dengue, chikungunya and yellow fever viruses. The project involves graduate students and postdoctoral trainees and results will be disseminated through seminars, conference presentations and journal publications.

The goals of this project are: (i) Since dengue, chikungunya and Zika viruses have significant agreement in their spatiotemporal distributions, the PIs will develop a multi-scale (multi-region) multi-patch model to study the geographical spread of VBD. A large scale is used to describe the long distance human movement from regions to regions and a small scale is used to model the short distance movement of both mosquitoes and humans from patches to patches within a region. The model will be applied to simulate the geographical and local spread of Zika among Miami Beach, Wynwood, and Little River in 2016 and will be studied employing multiple scale analysis and slow-fast dynamical system theory. (ii) Since age distributions of both vectors and hosts are very important in the spread of VBD, the PIs will construct age-structured models to study the effect of age distributions of both mosquitoes and humans on the transmission of VBD and use the model to design optimal vector control policies and to access disease risk for different age groups. (iii) Since age-structured models can be written as abstract equations in Banach spaces and seasonality imposes a natural temporal period, the PIs will study the nonlinear dynamics of semilinear periodic equations and apply the results to age-structured VBD models with seasonal change. Studying the nonlinear dynamics of periodic solutions in the semilinear periodic Cauchy problem will be transformative since the results will be useful in studying periodic delay equation models, time-periodic reaction-diffusion equations, and age-structured periodic models arising from biology and epidemiology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Several vector-borne diseases (VBDs), such as dengue, chikungunya and Zika, have been imported into Florida, have caused local outbreaks (dengue in 2009-2010 and 2013, chikungunya in 2014, Zika in 2016), and have posed a major public health problem. Dengue, chikungunya and Zika share the same primary vectors, Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus, both abundantly found in Florida and capable of transmitting several other diseases. In order to study the transmission dynamics of these VBD, it is necessary to understand the population dynamics of the mosquitoes that transmit these diseases.  In this project, the PIs (Dr. S. Ruan, Dr. J. C. Beier, Dr. X. Huo, Dr. J. Chen) have developed mathematical models to understand the growth, invasion, competition, and control of Aedes mosquitoes. For instance, in Lou et al. (J. Math. Biol. 2019), a novel modeling framework was proposed to investigate the effects of diapause on seasonal population growth of mosquito populations, where the diapause period is taken as an independent growth process, during which the population dynamics are completely.  This was the first piece of study on modeling the diapause of mosquitoes and may shed light on the diapause-induced variations in spatiotemporal distributions of different mosquito species. Releasing sterile mosquitoes is a method of mosquito control that uses area-wide inundative releases of sterile male mosquitoes to reduce reproduction in a field population of wild mosquitoes.  In Huang et al. (SIAM J. Appl. Dynam. Syst. 2019), a mosquito population model with a nonlinear saturated release rate of sterile mosquitoes was considered and the complex dynamics and bifurcations of the model were studied. In Liu, Tian and Ruan (SIAM J. Appl. Math. 2020), a two-species competition model in a network (that is, with discrete Laplacian diffusion) was proposed to investigate and simulate the invasion of the Ae. Albopictus mosquitoes and the competition between Ae. albopictus and Ae. aegypti mosquitoes in the U.S.  Huo et al.  (Acta Tropica 2023) developed a time dependent ODE model to study the local mosquito population dynamics in Miami-Dade County. By using local entomological and temperature data, the PIs used the model to calibrate the mosquito trap data from 2017 to 2019, and used the model to compare the Ae. aegypti population and evaluated the impact of rainfall intensity in different urban built environments. The results show that rainfall affects the breeding sites and the abundance of Ae. aegypti more significantly in tourist areas than in residential places. In addition, the model was applied to quantitatively assess the effectiveness of vector control strategies in Miami-Dade County. Wang, Lin and Ruan (Proc. R. Soc. Edinburgh A 2023) studied spreading speeds and traveling wave solutions of diffusive vector-borne disease models.

The PIs also developed theories for the nonlinear dynamics of some new classes of equations including abstract semilinear periodic equations, first-order hyperbolic equations with two physiological structures and age-structured models with nonlocal diffusion. The results have been used by other researchers to study nonlinear dynamics of biological and epidemiological models described by these types of equations. The proposed project have resulted more than 30 publications. Moreover, the PIs presented talks on their findings at various national and international conferences and were actively involved in the training of undergraduate and graduate students.


Last Modified: 08/10/2023
Modified by: Shigui Ruan
